1.1.1 Computer Hardware Basics: CPU, RAM, HDD, SSD, GPU

Understanding Core Computer Components

Modern computers are built upon five fundamental hardware components that work together to process, store, and display information. Understanding these components is essential for any IT professional, especially in cybersecurity where hardware vulnerabilities and performance impact security measures.

1. Central Processing Unit (CPU)

The CPU is the "brain" of the computer, executing instructions and performing calculations. It processes data from programs, the operating system, and user inputs.

Key CPU Specifications:

SpecificationDescriptionImpact on Performance
Clock Speed (GHz)Frequency at which CPU executes instructionsHigher = faster processing per core
CoresIndependent processing units within CPUMore cores = better multitasking
Cache (L1, L2, L3)Fast memory built into CPULarger cache = faster data access
ThreadsVirtual cores through hyperthreadingImproved parallel processing

Example: CPU Specifications Comparison

Intel Core i7-12700K:
- Cores: 12 (8 Performance + 4 Efficient)
- Threads: 20
- Base Clock: 3.6 GHz
- Turbo Clock: 5.0 GHz
- Cache: 25 MB
- TDP: 125W

AMD Ryzen 7 5800X:
- Cores: 8
- Threads: 16
- Base Clock: 3.8 GHz
- Boost Clock: 4.7 GHz
- Cache: 36 MB
- TDP: 105W

2. Random Access Memory (RAM)

RAM is volatile memory that temporarily stores data and programs currently in use. Unlike storage drives, RAM loses all data when power is turned off.

RAM Types and Characteristics:

RAM TypeSpeed RangeVoltageUse Case
DDR3800-2133 MHz1.5VLegacy systems (2007-2015)
DDR42133-3200 MHz1.2VCurrent mainstream (2014-present)
DDR54800-6400 MHz1.1VModern high-performance (2021+)

Office Work:              8-16 GB

Video Editing:            32-64 GB
Virtualization/Servers:   64-128+ GB
Security Testing Labs:    16-32 GB (for running multiple VMs)

3. Storage: Hard Disk Drive (HDD) vs Solid State Drive (SSD)

HDD (Hard Disk Drive)

Mechanical storage using spinning magnetic platters and read/write heads. Offers high capacity at lower cost but slower performance.

SSD (Solid State Drive)

Electronic storage using NAND flash memory chips. Faster, more durable, but more expensive per gigabyte.

FeatureHDDSATA SSDNVMe SSD

Write Speed80-160 MB/s200-520 MB/s2,000-5,000 MB/s

4. Graphics Processing Unit (GPU)

The GPU renders images, videos, and animations. Modern GPUs are also used for parallel processing tasks like cryptocurrency mining, AI/ML, and password cracking in cybersecurity.

GPU Types:

TypeDescriptionAdvantagesDisadvantages
Integrated GPUBuilt into CPULower cost, less power consumptionLimited performance
Dedicated GPUSeparate graphics cardHigh performance, upgradeableHigher cost, more power/heat

GPU in Cybersecurity Context:

# Password cracking with GPU acceleration (Example concept)
# GPUs can test millions of password combinations per second

CPU-based cracking:    ~10,000 hashes/second
GPU-based cracking:    ~10,000,000 hashes/second

Real-world example (MD5 hash):
- 8-character password (lowercase + numbers)
- CPU: ~2.5 hours to crack
- GPU (RTX 3090): ~8 seconds to crack

Security Implication:
This demonstrates why strong passwords (12+ characters, 
mixed case, symbols) are essential for security.

Component Interaction Example

Boot Sequence - How Components Work Together:
  
1. Power On → Power Supply Unit (PSU) powers all components
2. CPU executes BIOS/UEFI from ROM chip
3. RAM is tested and initialized (POST - Power-On Self-Test)
4. Storage (HDD/SSD) is detected and boot sector is read
5. Operating System is loaded from storage into RAM
6. GPU initializes and displays boot screen
7. CPU processes OS instructions from RAM
8. System ready for user interaction

Data Flow Example - Opening a Program:
1. User clicks application icon
2. CPU receives input signal
3. CPU requests program data from storage (HDD/SSD)
4. Program code loads into RAM
5. CPU executes program instructions from RAM
6. GPU renders application interface
7. Display shows program window

Practical Considerations for IT Professionals

Choosing Components for Security Labs:

  • CPU: Multi-core processor (6+ cores) for running multiple virtual machines simultaneously
  • RAM: 32GB minimum for virtualization environments (VirtualBox, VMware)
  • Storage: NVMe SSD for OS and applications, HDD for data archives and backups
  • GPU: Mid-range for password auditing tools like Hashcat or John the Ripper

Key Takeaways

  • CPU determines processing power and multitasking capability
  • RAM affects how many programs can run simultaneously and system responsiveness
  • SSDs provide dramatically faster performance than HDDs for OS and applications
  • GPUs are critical for graphics-intensive tasks and parallel processing in security testing
  • Understanding hardware helps diagnose performance issues and security vulnerabilities

Introduction to Computer Peripherals

Peripherals are external or internal devices that connect to a computer to provide input, output, or additional functionality. These devices enable human-computer interaction and extend system capabilities. For cybersecurity professionals, understanding peripherals is crucial as they can be vectors for attacks (e.g., keyloggers, malicious USB devices).

1.1.3 Computer Hardware Basics: Hardware Troubleshooting

Introduction to Hardware Troubleshooting

Hardware troubleshooting is the systematic process of diagnosing and resolving physical component failures and performance issues. As an IT professional, developing strong troubleshooting skills is essential for maintaining system uptime and quickly identifying whether problems are hardware or software-related.

The Troubleshooting Methodology

Professional hardware troubleshooting follows a structured approach to efficiently identify and resolve issues:

StepActionKey Questions/Tasks
1. Identify the ProblemGather informationWhat changed? When did it start? Can you reproduce it?
2. Establish TheoryFormulate probable causeWhat are the most likely culprits? Check simple things first
3. Test the TheoryVerify hypothesisDoes testing confirm the theory? If not, establish new theory
4. Create Action PlanDetermine resolutionWhat needs to be replaced/repaired? What are the risks?
5. Implement SolutionExecute the fixFollow safety procedures, document changes
6. Verify FunctionalityTest the systemDoes the original problem still occur? Any new issues?
7. DocumentRecord the solutionWhat was the problem? What fixed it? Prevention measures?

Common Hardware Problems and Solutions

1. System Won't Power On

Symptom: No lights, no fans, no response when pressing power button

Troubleshooting Steps:
1. Check power source
   □ Is power cord connected firmly?
   □ Is wall outlet working? (Test with lamp)
   □ Is power strip/UPS functioning?
   □ Try different power cable

2. Check power supply unit (PSU)
   □ Is PSU switch on? (Back of PC)
   □ Test with PSU tester or multimeter
   □ Listen for PSU fan spinning
   
3. Check internal connections
   □ Reseat 24-pin motherboard power connector
   □ Reseat 8-pin CPU power connector
   □ Check front panel power button connection
   
4. Isolate components
   □ Disconnect all peripherals
   □ Remove all but one RAM stick
   □ Disconnect non-essential components
   
5. Test power button
   □ Short the power pins on motherboard directly
   
Solution Priority:
1st - Power cable/outlet (75% of cases)
2nd - PSU failure (15% of cases)  
3rd - Motherboard failure (8% of cases)
4th - Other components (2% of cases)

2. System Powers On But No Display

Symptom DetailsLikely CauseDiagnostic Steps
No beep codes, fans spinRAM not detectedReseat RAM, try one stick at a time, clean contacts
One long beep, two shortGPU failure (Award BIOS)Reseat GPU, check power cables, test integrated graphics
Continuous beepingRAM failureRemove and test each RAM stick individually
Display "No Signal"Cable/monitor issueCheck cable connections, try different cable/port
Three beeps, pause, repeatMemory error (AMI BIOS)Test RAM with MemTest86, replace faulty modules

Beep Code Reference:

AMI BIOS Beep Codes:
1 beep:   DRAM refresh failure
2 beeps:  Parity circuit failure
3 beeps:  Base 64K RAM failure
4 beeps:  System timer failure
5 beeps:  Processor failure
6 beeps:  Keyboard controller failure
7 beeps:  Virtual mode exception error
8 beeps:  Display memory R/W test failure
9 beeps:  ROM BIOS checksum failure
10 beeps: CMOS shutdown R/W error

Award BIOS Beep Codes:
Long continuous beep:      No RAM detected
1 long, 2 short beeps:     Video card error
1 long, 3 short beeps:     Video memory error
Repeating high/low beeps:  CPU overheating

3. Random Crashes and Restarts

Symptom: System unexpectedly shuts down or restarts during use

Common Causes & Solutions:

A) OVERHEATING
   Symptoms: Crashes during intensive tasks, hot case
   
   Diagnostic:
   # Check CPU temperature (Linux)
   $ sensors
   # Check CPU temperature (Windows PowerShell)
   Get-WmiObject MSAcpi_ThermalZoneTemperature -Namespace root/wmi
   
   Safe Temperatures:
   - CPU idle: 30-45°C
   - CPU load: 60-80°C
   - GPU idle: 30-50°C
   - GPU load: 60-85°C
   
   Solutions:
   □ Clean dust from fans and heatsinks (compressed air)
   □ Replace thermal paste on CPU
   □ Verify all fans are spinning
   □ Improve case airflow
   □ Check CPU cooler mounting pressure

B) POWER SUPPLY ISSUES
   Symptoms: Random shutoffs, especially under load
   
   Diagnostic:
   □ Calculate total power draw vs PSU capacity
   □ Test with PSU tester
   □ Monitor voltage rails with HWMonitor
   
   Voltage Tolerances (ATX specification):
   +12V: 11.4V - 12.6V
   +5V:  4.75V - 5.25V
   +3.3V: 3.14V - 3.47V
   
   Solution:
   □ Replace undersized or failing PSU
   □ Use PSU calculator to determine needed wattage

C) RAM ERRORS
   Symptoms: Random crashes, blue screens, corrupted files
   
   Diagnostic:
   # Windows Memory Diagnostic
   mdsched.exe
   # Linux - MemTest86+ (boot from USB)
   # Run for minimum 4 passes
   
   Solution:
   □ Replace faulty RAM modules
   □ Lower RAM frequency in BIOS
   □ Increase RAM voltage slightly (if stable)

D) FAILING HARD DRIVE
   Symptoms: Freezes, slow performance, clicking sounds
   
   Diagnostic:
   # Check SMART status (Linux)
   $ sudo smartctl -a /dev/sda
   # Check SMART status (Windows)
   wmic diskdrive get status
   
   Critical SMART Attributes:
   - Reallocated Sectors Count (ID 5)
   - Current Pending Sector Count (ID 197)
   - Uncorrectable Sector Count (ID 198)
   
   Solution:
   □ Backup data immediately
   □ Replace drive
   □ Check SATA cables and connections

4. Performance Issues

SymptomHardware CauseHow to VerifySolution
Slow boot timesHDD instead of SSDCheck disk type in BIOS/Device ManagerUpgrade to SSD
System freezesInsufficient RAMMonitor RAM usage (Task Manager)Add more RAM
Slow application loadingFailing/slow storageRun CrystalDiskMark benchmarkReplace storage device
Poor gaming/graphics performanceWeak/failing GPUMonitor GPU usage & tempsUpdate drivers or replace GPU
Throttling during heavy workloadCPU overheatingMonitor temps with HWMonitorImprove cooling solution

Diagnostic Tools and Commands

Software Diagnostic Tools:

HARDWARE MONITORING:
- HWMonitor:        Temperatures, voltages, fan speeds
- CPU-Z:            CPU, motherboard, RAM information
- GPU-Z:            Graphics card specifications and monitoring
- CrystalDiskInfo:  Drive health and SMART data
- MemTest86:        RAM testing (bootable)
- Prime95:          CPU stress testing
- FurMark:          GPU stress testing
- CrystalDiskMark:  Storage performance benchmarking

# Device Manager

# Disk Management

# Event Viewer (hardware errors)

$ inxi -Fxz

$ fdisk -l

# Kernel messages (hardware errors)
$ dmesg | grep -i error

Physical Hardware Testing

Component Isolation Testing:

Minimum POST (Power-On Self-Test) Configuration:
□ Motherboard
□ CPU with cooler
□ Single RAM stick
□ Power supply
□ Power button connection (or screwdriver to short pins)
□ Monitor connection (integrated graphics or basic GPU)

Procedure:
1. Remove ALL components except minimum POST config
2. Power on system outside of case (on motherboard box)
3. If successful boot → Add components one at a time
4. Test after each addition to identify faulty component
5. If no POST → Swap RAM, test different slot
6. Still no POST → CPU or motherboard failure

RAM Testing Protocol:
1. Test one stick at a time in primary slot (usually DIMM1/A1)
2. If system boots, run MemTest86 for 4+ passes
3. Repeat for each stick
4. Test working sticks in each motherboard slot
5. Identify: bad RAM stick or bad motherboard slot

Preventive Maintenance

TaskFrequencyPurposeTools Needed
Clean dust from componentsEvery 3-6 monthsPrevent overheatingCompressed air, anti-static brush
Check cable connectionsEvery 6 monthsPrevent loose connection issuesNone
Monitor SMART dataMonthlyPredict drive failuresCrystalDiskInfo or smartctl
Update firmware/BIOSAs neededSecurity patches, bug fixesManufacturer utilities
Replace thermal pasteEvery 2-3 yearsMaintain cooling efficiencyThermal paste, isopropyl alcohol
Test backupsMonthlyEnsure data recovery capabilityBackup software

Safety and Best Practices

  • ESD Protection: Use anti-static wrist strap or touch grounded metal before handling components
  • Power Safety: Always unplug system before working inside; discharge capacitors by pressing power button 10 seconds
  • Component Handling: Hold RAM and cards by edges, never touch gold contacts or circuit components
  • Proper Tools: Use magnetic screwdrivers, proper size bits to avoid stripping screws
  • Documentation: Take photos before disassembly; label cable connections
  • Workspace: Use clean, well-lit area with non-conductive surface
  • Backup First: Always backup critical data before hardware changes or troubleshooting

Troubleshooting Decision Tree

Computer Problem Decision Tree:

Does system power on?
├─ NO → Check power supply, connections, PSU
└─ YES → Any display output?
    ├─ NO → Check monitor, cables, GPU, RAM (beep codes)
    └─ YES → Does OS load?
        ├─ NO → Check boot drive, boot order, OS files
        └─ YES → Performance issues?
            ├─ Slow → Check temps, RAM usage, disk health
            ├─ Crashes → Check temps, RAM errors, PSU, drivers
            └─ Errors → Check Event Viewer, SMART data, run diagnostics

Hardware vs Software Issue Indicators:

HARDWARE:
✓ Problems persist across OS reinstall
✓ Issues occur in BIOS/before OS loads
✓ Physical symptoms (heat, noise, smell)
✓ Beep codes or LED error indicators
✓ Diagnostic tools show failing components

SOFTWARE:
✓ Problems started after software install/update
✓ Issues only in specific applications
✓ Problems resolve with driver updates
✓ Error messages reference specific programs
✓ Safe mode works correctly

Common Troubleshooting Mistakes to Avoid

MistakeWhy It's BadCorrect Approach
Changing multiple things at onceCan't identify which change fixed issueChange one variable at a time
Not documenting steps takenCan't replicate solution or undo changesKeep detailed notes of all actions
Assuming the obvious causeWastes time replacing wrong componentTest theories before replacing parts
Ignoring user reportsMiss critical clues about when/how problem occursInterview user thoroughly
Not checking simple things firstOverlook easy fixes, waste time on complex theoriesStart with cables, connections, power
Working without backupRisk permanent data lossAlways backup before troubleshooting

Advanced Diagnostic Scenarios

Scenario 1: Intermittent Display Issues
Problem: Screen occasionally goes black, then recovers
  
Investigation:
1. Check GPU temperature → Overheating?
2. Monitor GPU clock speeds → Throttling?
3. Test with different cable → Cable fault?
4. Try different display output → Port failure?
5. Check Event Viewer → Driver crashes?
6. Test GPU in different PCIe slot → Motherboard issue?
7. Test with different GPU → GPU hardware failure?

Resolution: If GPU temps spike during blackouts = 
            Reapply thermal paste or replace GPU cooler

Scenario 2: System Slow After Adding RAM
Problem: Added more RAM, but system is slower

Investigation:
1. Check RAM speed in BIOS/CPU-Z
2. Verify all sticks are same speed
3. Check if running in single-channel mode
4. Run MemTest86 for errors
5. Check if RAM is in correct slots for dual-channel

Common Issue: Mixing RAM speeds → All RAM runs at slowest speed
              Incorrect slot population → Single-channel instead of dual

Resolution: Ensure matched RAM pairs in correct slots
            (Usually A2+B2 or DIMM2+DIMM4 for dual-channel)

Scenario 3: Loud Fan Noise
Problem: Fans running at 100% constantly

Investigation:
1. Check BIOS fan curves → Improperly configured?
2. Monitor temps → Actually overheating?
3. Listen to identify which fan → Failing bearing?
4. Check fan headers connected correctly → Wrong header type?
5. Update BIOS → Fan control bug?

Resolution: If temps normal but fans loud → 
            Adjust fan curves in BIOS or use fan controller
            If bearing noise → Replace failing fan

Key Takeaways

  • Follow systematic troubleshooting methodology to efficiently identify root causes
  • Most hardware problems fall into predictable categories with known solutions
  • Beep codes and error patterns provide critical diagnostic information
  • Use appropriate diagnostic tools to test hardware functionality
  • Preventive maintenance reduces hardware failures significantly
  • Always prioritize data backup before hardware troubleshooting
  • Document problems and solutions for future reference

1.2.1 Connection Types: NFC (Near Field Communication)

Introduction to NFC Technology

Near Field Communication (NFC) is a short-range wireless technology that enables communication between devices when they are within close proximity (typically 4 cm or less). NFC operates on the principle of electromagnetic induction and is widely used for contactless payments, access control, data transfer, and authentication.

How NFC Works

NFC is based on Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) technology and operates at 13.56 MHz frequency. It uses electromagnetic induction between two loop antennas when they are brought close together.

Technical Specifications:

SpecificationValueDetails
Operating Frequency13.56 MHzISM band (Industrial, Scientific, Medical)
RangeUp to 4 cmTypically 1-2 cm for secure transactions
Data Rate106, 212, 424, 848 KbpsVaries based on mode and implementation
Power ConsumptionVery Low (< 15 mA)Can power passive tags through field
Setup Time< 0.1 secondsNearly instant connection

NFC Operating Modes

NFC supports three modes of operation:

1. READER/WRITER MODE
   - NFC device reads data from passive NFC tags
   - Common use: Reading smart posters, product information
   - Example: Scanning NFC tag on a museum exhibit
   
   Data Flow: Active Device → Passive Tag

2. PEER-TO-PEER MODE  
   - Two active NFC devices exchange information
   - Common use: File sharing, contact exchange
   - Example: Android Beam, quick Bluetooth pairing
   
   Data Flow: Active Device ↔ Active Device

3. CARD EMULATION MODE
   - NFC device acts as a contactless smart card
   - Common use: Mobile payments, access control
   - Example: Apple Pay, Google Pay, digital access badges
   
   Data Flow: Reader → Active Device (acting as card)

Setup Time< 0.1 s< 6 s3-10 s< 0.1 s

Introduction to Bluetooth Technology

Bluetooth is a short-range wireless communication technology that enables data exchange between devices over distances typically ranging from 1 to 100 meters. Developed by Ericsson in 1994 and standardized by the Bluetooth Special Interest Group (SIG), it operates in the 2.4 GHz ISM (Industrial, Scientific, and Medical) frequency band.

  • Range: Class 1 (100m), Class 2 (10m), Class 3 (1m)
  • Data Rate: Up to 3 Mbps (Bluetooth 5.0: up to 50 Mbps)
  • Network Topology: Piconet (1 master, up to 7 active slaves)

Introduction to WiFi Technology

WiFi (Wireless Fidelity) is a family of wireless network protocols based on the IEEE 802.11 standards. It enables devices to connect to local area networks (LANs) and the internet without physical cables. The Wi-Fi Alliance certifies products meeting these standards to ensure interoperability.

  • Range: Indoor: 30-50m, Outdoor: up to 100m+
  • Data Rate: 11 Mbps (802.11b) to 9.6 Gbps (WiFi 6E)
  • Network Architecture: Infrastructure (AP-based) or Ad-hoc (peer-to-peer)

2. AUTHENTICATION Phase
   # Open System Authentication (legacy)

from scapy.all import *

def packet_handler(pkt):
    """
    Process WiFi beacon frames and probe responses
    """
    if pkt.haslayer(Dot11Beacon) or pkt.haslayer(Dot11ProbeResp):
        # Extract BSSID (MAC address of AP)
        bssid = pkt[Dot11].addr2
        
        # Extract SSID
        try:
            ssid = pkt[Dot11Elt].info.decode()
        except:
            ssid = ""
        
        # Get channel
        try:
            channel = int(ord(pkt[Dot11Elt:3].info))
        except:
            channel = 0
        
        # Get encryption type
        crypto = "Open"
        if pkt.haslayer(Dot11Elt):
            capability = pkt.sprintf("{Dot11Beacon:%Dot11Beacon.cap%}")
            if "privacy" in capability.lower():
                if pkt.haslayer(RSN):
                    crypto = "WPA3/WPA2"
                elif pkt.haslayer(WPA):
                    crypto = "WPA"
                else:
                    crypto = "WEP"
        
        # Signal strength
        try:
            signal_strength = pkt.dBm_AntSignal
        except:
            signal_strength = "N/A"
        
        network = {
            "BSSID": bssid,
            "SSID": ssid,
            "Channel": channel,
            "Encryption": crypto,
            "Signal (dBm)": signal_strength,
            "Timestamp": datetime.now().strftime("%H:%M:%S")
        }
        
        # Avoid duplicates
        if bssid not in [n["BSSID"] for n in networks]:
            networks.append(network)
            print(f"[+] Found network: {ssid} ({bssid}) - {crypto}")

    # Display results

        print("\n" + "="*80)
        print("DISCOVERED NETWORKS:")
        print("="*80)

    else:

# Execute scan

// Secure IR transmission with rolling codes (C++)

#include <Arduino.h>
#include <IRremote.h>

class SecureIR {
private:
    uint32_t rollingCode;
    uint32_t secretKey;
    
    // Simple encryption (use proper crypto in production!)
    uint32_t encrypt(uint32_t data) {
        return data ^ secretKey ^ rollingCode;
    }
    
    uint32_t decrypt(uint32_t data) {
        return data ^ secretKey ^ rollingCode;
    }
    
    // Generate next rolling code
    void updateRollingCode() {
        // Linear Congruential Generator
        rollingCode = (rollingCode * 1103515245 + 12345) & 0x7FFFFFFF;
    }

public:
    SecureIR(uint32_t key) : secretKey(key), rollingCode(0x12345678) {}
    
    void sendSecureData(uint8_t command, IRsend& irsend) {
        // Create packet: [Rolling Code][Command][CRC]
        uint32_t packet = 0;
        packet |= (rollingCode & 0xFFFF) << 16;  // 16-bit rolling code
        packet |= (command & 0xFF) << 8;          // 8-bit command
        
        // Calculate simple checksum
        uint8_t checksum = calculateChecksum(packet);
        packet |= checksum;
        
        // Encrypt packet
        uint32_t encryptedPacket = encrypt(packet);
        
        // Transmit
        irsend.sendNEC(encryptedPacket, 32);
        
        // Update rolling code for next transmission
        updateRollingCode();
    }
    
    bool receiveSecureData(decode_results& results, uint8_t& command) {
        if (results.decode_type != NEC) return false;
        
        // Decrypt packet
        uint32_t packet = decrypt(results.value);
        
        // Extract components
        uint16_t receivedCode = (packet >> 16) & 0xFFFF;
        command = (packet >> 8) & 0xFF;
        uint8_t receivedChecksum = packet & 0xFF;
        
        // Verify rolling code (allow small window for sync)
        if (abs((int32_t)receivedCode - (int32_t)(rollingCode & 0xFFFF)) > 10) {
            return false;  // Replay attack detected
        }
        
        // Verify checksum
        if (receivedChecksum != calculateChecksum(packet)) {
            return false;  // Data corruption
        }
        
        // Update rolling code
        updateRollingCode();
        return true;
    }
    
    uint8_t calculateChecksum(uint32_t data) {
        uint8_t sum = 0;
        for(int i = 0; i < 4; i++) {
            sum += (data >> (i * 8)) & 0xFF;
        }
        return sum;
    }
};

Linux dominates server infrastructure with over 96% of the world's top 1 million web servers running Linux.

Linux follows the Unix philosophy emphasizing modularity, simplicity, and the principle that "everything is a file." Key principles include:

  • Open Source: Source code freely available for inspection, modification, and distribution
  • Modularity: Small programs that do one thing well and can be combined
  • Multi-user: Multiple users can work simultaneously with proper isolation

    For clean installation on new/empty disk:
    → Select unallocated space → Click "New" → Apply

assign letter=c

Understanding Linux System Configuration

After installing Linux, proper system configuration is crucial for security, performance, and usability. Linux configuration is primarily file-based, with most settings stored in text files under the /etc directory. This module covers essential post-installation configurations every Linux user and cybersecurity professional must master.

Critical Configuration Files

File PathPurposeFormat
/etc/hostnameSystem hostnamePlain text (single line)
/etc/hostsStatic hostname-to-IP mappingsIP address, hostname pairs
/etc/network/interfacesNetwork interface configuration (Debian)Structured configuration
/etc/resolv.confDNS resolver settingsnameserver directives
/etc/fstabFilesystem mount pointsDevice, mount point, type, options
/etc/passwdUser account informationColon-separated fields
/etc/shadowEncrypted passwordsColon-separated, restricted access
/etc/groupGroup definitionsGroup name, GID, members
/etc/sudoersSudo privileges configurationSpecial syntax (edit with visudo)
/etc/ssh/sshd_configSSH server configurationKey-value pairs

1. User and Group Management

Creating and Managing Users

# Create a new user
sudo useradd -m -s /bin/bash john
# -m: create home directory
# -s: specify shell

# Set password
sudo passwd john

# Create user with more options
sudo useradd -m -s /bin/bash -G sudo,docker -c "John Doe" john
# -G: add to additional groups
# -c: comment/full name

# Modify existing user
sudo usermod -aG sudo john     # Add to sudo group
sudo usermod -s /bin/zsh john  # Change shell
sudo usermod -L john           # Lock account
sudo usermod -U john           # Unlock account

# Delete user
sudo userdel john              # Keep home directory
sudo userdel -r john           # Remove home directory

# View user information
id john                        # User ID and groups
whoami                         # Current user
w                              # Who is logged in
last                           # Login history

Group Management

# Create group
sudo groupadd developers

# Add user to group
sudo usermod -aG developers john
# or
sudo gpasswd -a john developers

# Remove user from group
sudo gpasswd -d john developers

# Delete group
sudo groupdel developers

# View groups
groups john                    # Groups for specific user
cat /etc/group                 # All groups

2. Network Configuration

Network Configuration Methods Comparison

ToolUsed InPersistenceComplexity

Static IP Configuration (Netplan - Ubuntu)

# Edit netplan configuration
sudo nano /etc/netplan/01-netcfg.yaml

# Static IP configuration example:
network:
  version: 2
  renderer: networkd
  ethernets:
    enp0s3:
      dhcp4: no
      addresses:
        - 192.168.1.100/24
      gateway4: 192.168.1.1
      nameservers:
        addresses:
          - 8.8.8.8
          - 8.8.4.4
        search:
          - localdomain

# Apply configuration
sudo netplan apply

# Test configuration first
sudo netplan try  # Reverts after 120s if not confirmed

# Check routing table

5. Firewall Configuration (UFW)

# Enable UFW firewall
sudo ufw enable

# Check status
sudo ufw status verbose

# Default policies
sudo ufw default deny incoming
sudo ufw default allow outgoing

# Allow specific services
sudo ufw allow ssh                 # Port 22
sudo ufw allow 80/tcp              # HTTP
sudo ufw allow 443/tcp             # HTTPS
sudo ufw allow from 192.168.1.0/24 # Allow from subnet

# Allow specific port range
sudo ufw allow 6000:6007/tcp

# Deny specific
sudo ufw deny 23                   # Deny Telnet

# Delete rule
sudo ufw delete allow 80

# Advanced rule examples
sudo ufw allow from 192.168.1.100 to any port 22
sudo ufw allow in on enp0s3 to any port 3306  # MySQL on specific interface

# View numbered rules
sudo ufw status numbered

# Delete by number
sudo ufw delete 2

# Reset firewall
sudo ufw reset

6. SSH Server Hardening

# Edit SSH configuration
sudo nano /etc/ssh/sshd_config

# Recommended security settings:
Port 2222                              # Change default port
PermitRootLogin no                     # Disable root login
PasswordAuthentication no              # Use key-based auth only
PubkeyAuthentication yes               # Enable SSH keys
PermitEmptyPasswords no                # No empty passwords
MaxAuthTries 3                         # Limit auth attempts
ClientAliveInterval 300                # Timeout idle sessions
ClientAliveCountMax 2
AllowUsers john admin                  # Whitelist users
Protocol 2                             # Use SSH protocol 2

# Apply changes
sudo systemctl restart sshd

# Generate SSH key pair (client side)
ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "your_email@example.com"
# or RSA 4096
ssh-keygen -t rsa -b 4096 -C "your_email@example.com"

# Copy public key to server
ssh-copy-id -i ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub user@server_ip

# Manual copy method
cat ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub | ssh user@server 'mkdir -p ~/.ssh && cat >> ~/.ssh/authorized_keys'

7. Time and Timezone Configuration

# Check current time and timezone
timedatectl

# List available timezones
timedatectl list-timezones

# Set timezone
sudo timedatectl set-timezone America/New_York

# Enable NTP (Network Time Protocol)
sudo timedatectl set-ntp true

# Install and configure chrony (alternative NTP)
sudo apt install chrony
sudo systemctl enable chrony
sudo systemctl start chrony

# Check synchronization status
chronyc tracking

SSHDisable root login, use key authenticationCritical
FirewallEnable UFW and configure rulesCritical
TimezoneSet correct timezone and enable NTPMedium
ServicesDisable unnecessary servicesHigh
LoggingConfigure centralized loggingMedium
BackupsSet up automated backup systemHigh

Key Takeaways

  • Linux configuration is primarily file-based; always backup configuration files before editing
  • Use sudo for administrative tasks instead of logging in as root
  • Network configuration varies by distribution; Ubuntu uses Netplan, Debian uses interfaces file
  • systemd is the modern init system and service manager in most Linux distributions
  • UFW provides a user-friendly interface to iptables firewall
  • SSH hardening is critical: disable root login, use key-based authentication, change default port
  • Always test network configuration changes with netplan try to avoid lockout
  • Document all configuration changes for troubleshooting and disaster recovery

The Power of the Command Line

The Command Line Interface (CLI) is the most powerful way to interact with Linux systems. While GUI tools are intuitive for basic tasks, the CLI provides precision, automation capabilities, remote system management, and is essential for cybersecurity professionals who work with servers, perform penetration testing, or automate security tasks. Mastering the CLI is non-negotiable for serious IT and security work.

Understanding the Shell

Command Structure Anatomy

Basic Command Structure:
command [options] [arguments]

Example breakdown:
sudo apt install -y vim
│    │   │       │  │
│    │   │       │  └─ Argument (package name)
│    │   │       └──── Option (auto-yes)
│    │   └──────────── Subcommand
│    └──────────────── Command
└───────────────────── Privilege escalation

Option formats:
- Short: -a, -l, -h (can combine: -alh)
- Long: --all, --list, --help

Common patterns:
command --help          # Get help
man command             # Manual page
command -v              # Verbose output
command -r              # Recursive operation

2.4.1 OS File Operations: Creating Files

Understanding File Creation in Operating Systems

File creation is one of the fundamental operations in any operating system. When a file is created, the OS allocates space on the storage device, creates metadata entries in the file system, and establishes pointers to the file's location. Understanding how different operating systems handle file creation is crucial for system administrators, developers, and cybersecurity professionals.

File Creation Process Overview

When you create a file, the operating system performs several critical operations behind the scenes:

StepOperationDescription
1Permission CheckOS verifies user has write permissions in target directory
2Space AllocationFile system allocates disk blocks for file storage
3Inode/MFT EntryCreates metadata entry (inode in Unix/Linux, MFT in Windows)
4Directory UpdateAdds file entry to parent directory structure
5File DescriptorReturns file handle/descriptor to the calling process

File Creation Methods Across Operating Systems

Linux/Unix Systems

Linux uses system calls like open(), creat(), and touch command for file creation.

Command Line Examples:

# Using redirection to create file with content

# Using cat command

This is line 2
EOF

# Using advanced options with touch

# Verify file creation

C Programming Example (Linux):

#include <unistd.h>

    int fd;

    if (fd == -1) {
        perror("Error creating file");
        return 1;
    }
    
    write(fd, "Hello from C program\n", 21);
    close(fd);
    
    printf("File created successfully\n");
    return 0;
}

# Python - Atomic file creation (prevents race conditions)
import os
import tempfile

def atomic_write(filepath, content):
    # Write to temporary file first
    fd, temp_path = tempfile.mkstemp(dir=os.path.dirname(filepath))
    try:
        with os.fdopen(fd, 'w') as f:
            f.write(content)

Security Considerations

File Creation Security Best Practices

  • Validate File Paths: Prevent directory traversal attacks (../ sequences)
  • Set Restrictive Permissions: Use 0600 or 0644, avoid 0777
  • Use Secure Temporary Directories: /tmp with sticky bit or user-specific temp dirs
  • Check for Race Conditions: Use O_EXCL flag to prevent TOCTOU attacks
  • Sanitize File Names: Remove special characters and validate length

Secure File Creation Example

import os
import re
from pathlib import Path

def secure_file_create(directory, filename, content):
    # Validate directory
    base_dir = Path(directory).resolve()
    if not base_dir.exists():
        raise ValueError("Directory does not exist")
    
    # Sanitize filename - remove dangerous characters
    safe_filename = re.sub(r'[^a-zA-Z0-9._-]', '_', filename)
    
    # Prevent directory traversal
    file_path = (base_dir / safe_filename).resolve()
    if not str(file_path).startswith(str(base_dir)):
        raise ValueError("Invalid file path - traversal detected")
    
    # Check if file exists
    if file_path.exists():
        raise FileExistsError(f"{safe_filename} already exists")
    
    # Create with restrictive permissions
    old_umask = os.umask(0o077)  # Creates files with 0600
    try:
        with open(file_path, 'w') as f:
            f.write(content)
    finally:
        os.umask(old_umask)
    
    return file_path

# Usage
try:
    result = secure_file_create('/var/app/data', 'user_input.txt', 'Safe content')
    print(f"File created securely at: {result}")
except Exception as e:
    print(f"Error: {e}")

Key Takeaways

  • File creation involves multiple OS operations: permission checks, space allocation, metadata updates
  • Different operating systems use different system calls (open/creat in Unix, CreateFile in Windows)
  • Always set appropriate permissions when creating files (0644 for regular files, 0600 for sensitive data)
  • Use atomic operations to prevent race conditions in multi-threaded/multi-process environments
  • Validate and sanitize file names to prevent security vulnerabilities like directory traversal
  • Handle exceptions properly - check for permission errors, disk space, and existing files
  • Temporary files should be created in secure locations with restrictive permissions

Whether loading configuration files, processing user data, or executing programs, file reading is fundamental to system operation. import os
from pathlib import Path

def secure_file_read(base_directory, filename, max_size=10*1024*1024):  # 10MB limit
    """
    Securely read a file with validation and size limits
    """
    # Resolve to absolute paths
    base_dir = Path(base_directory).resolve()
    file_path = (base_dir / filename).resolve()
    
    # Prevent directory traversal
    if not str(file_path).startswith(str(base_dir)):
        raise ValueError("Path traversal detected")
    
    # Check file exists and is a regular file (not symlink, directory, etc.)
    if not file_path.is_file():
        raise ValueError("Not a regular file")
    
    # Check file size before reading
    file_size = file_path.stat().st_size
    if file_size > max_size:
        raise ValueError(f"File too large: {file_size} bytes")
    
    # Check read permissions
    if not os.access(file_path, os.R_OK):
        raise PermissionError("File not readable")
    
    try:
        # Read with controlled encoding
        with open(file_path, 'r', encoding='utf-8', errors='strict') as f:
            content = f.read(max_size)  # Additional safety limit
        return content
    except UnicodeDecodeError:
        raise ValueError("Invalid file encoding")
    except Exception as e:
        # Log error securely without exposing path details
        print(f"Error reading file: {type(e).__name__}")
        raise

# Usage example
try:
    content = secure_file_read('/var/app/data', 'user_file.txt')
    print("File read successfully")
except Exception as e:
    print(f"Error: {e}")

  • Always use context managers (with statement): Ensures files are properly closed even if exceptions occur
  • Handle encoding explicitly: Specify encoding (UTF-8, ASCII) to avoid platform-dependent behavior
  • Validate file paths: Prevent directory traversal and unauthorized access
  • Implement size limits: Prevent memory exhaustion from large files
  • Use buffered reading for large files: Process in chunks to manage memory efficiently
  • Check permissions before reading: Fail gracefully with appropriate error messages
  • Close file descriptors: Especially important in long-running applications

import os
import hashlib
import json

class SafeFileUpdater:
    def __init__(self, filepath):
        self.filepath = filepath
    
    def calculate_checksum(self, content):
        return hashlib.sha256(content.encode()).hexdigest()
    
    def atomic_update_with_verification(self, new_content):
        # Read original
        try:
            with open(self.filepath, 'r') as f:
                original_content = f.read()
                original_checksum = self.calculate_checksum(original_content)
        except FileNotFoundError:
            original_content = ""
            original_checksum = None
        
        # Calculate new checksum
        new_checksum = self.calculate_checksum(new_content)
        
        # Create temp file
        temp_path = self.filepath + '.tmp'
        backup_path = self.filepath + '.backup'
        
        try:
            # Write new content to temp
            with open(temp_path, 'w') as f:
                f.write(new_content)
                f.flush()
                os.fsync(f.fileno())
            
            # Verify temp file
            with open(temp_path, 'r') as f:
                verify_content = f.read()
                verify_checksum = self.calculate_checksum(verify_content)
            
            if verify_checksum != new_checksum:
                raise ValueError("Checksum mismatch after write")
            
            # Backup original
            if original_checksum:
                os.rename(self.filepath, backup_path)
            
            # Atomic rename
            os.rename(temp_path, self.filepath)
            
            # Store metadata
            metadata = {
                'checksum': new_checksum,
                'timestamp': time.time(),
                'previous_checksum': original_checksum
            }
            
            with open(self.filepath + '.meta', 'w') as f:
                json.dump(metadata, f)
            
            # Remove backup after successful update
            if os.path.exists(backup_path):
                os.remove(backup_path)
            
            return True
            
        except Exception as e:
            # Restore from backup on failure
            if os.path.exists(backup_path):
                os.rename(backup_path, self.filepath)
            if os.path.exists(temp_path):
                os.remove(temp_path)
            raise

# Usage

updater.atomic_update_with_verification('New critical content')

  • Consider file size: Use streaming for large files to manage memory
  • Preserve metadata: Maintain ownership, permissions, timestamps when appropriate

    struct stat st;
    
    // Check if file exists
    if (stat(filepath, &st) == -1) {
        fprintf(stderr, "File does not exist: %s\n", filepath);
        return -1;
    }
    
    // Check if it's a regular file
    if (!S_ISREG(st.st_mode)) {
        fprintf(stderr, "Not a regular file: %s\n", filepath);
        return -1;
    }

        return -1;
    }

// Secure deletion - overwrite before delete
int secure_delete(const char *filepath) {
    struct stat st;
    FILE *fp;
    
    if (stat(filepath, &st) == -1) return -1;
    
    fp = fopen(filepath, "r+b");
    if (!fp) return -1;
    
    // Overwrite with zeros
    size_t size = st.st_size;
    unsigned char *zeros = calloc(1, size);
    fwrite(zeros, 1, size, fp);
    fflush(fp);
    fsync(fileno(fp));
    
    // Overwrite with random data
    FILE *urandom = fopen("/dev/urandom", "rb");
    unsigned char *random = malloc(size);
    fread(random, 1, size, urandom);
    fseek(fp, 0, SEEK_SET);
    fwrite(random, 1, size, fp);
    fflush(fp);
    fsync(fileno(fp));
    
    fclose(fp);
    fclose(urandom);
    free(zeros);
    free(random);
    
    // Finally delete
    return unlink(filepath);
}

Secure Deletion Implementation

import os
import secrets

class SecureDelete:
    @staticmethod
    def dod_delete(filepath, passes=3):
        """
        DoD 5220.22-M inspired deletion
        Pass 1: Write 0x00
        Pass 2: Write 0xFF
        Pass 3: Write random data
        """
        if not os.path.exists(filepath):
            return False
        
        file_size = os.path.getsize(filepath)
        
        with open(filepath, 'r+b') as f:
            # Pass 1: Zeros
            f.write(b'\x00' * file_size)
            f.flush()
            os.fsync(f.fileno())
            
            # Pass 2: Ones
            f.seek(0)
            f.write(b'\xFF' * file_size)
            f.flush()
            os.fsync(f.fileno())
            
            # Pass 3: Random
            f.seek(0)
            f.write(secrets.token_bytes(file_size))
            f.flush()
            os.fsync(f.fileno())
        
        # Delete file
        os.remove(filepath)
        return True
    
    @staticmethod
    def nist_delete(filepath):
        """
        NIST SP 800-88: Single pass with fixed value
        """
        if not os.path.exists(filepath):
            return False
        
        file_size = os.path.getsize(filepath)
        
        with open(filepath, 'r+b') as f:
            f.write(b'\x00' * file_size)
            f.flush()
            os.fsync(f.fileno())
        
        os.remove(filepath)
        return True
    
    @staticmethod
    def random_delete(filepath, passes=3):
        """
        Multiple passes of cryptographically secure random data
        """
        if not os.path.exists(filepath):
            return False
        
        file_size = os.path.getsize(filepath)
        
        with open(filepath, 'r+b') as f:
            for i in range(passes):
                f.seek(0)
                # Write in chunks for large files
                chunk_size = 1024 * 1024  # 1MB chunks
                remaining = file_size
                
                while remaining > 0:
                    chunk = min(chunk_size, remaining)
                    f.write(secrets.token_bytes(chunk))
                    remaining -= chunk
                
                f.flush()
                os.fsync(f.fileno())
        
        os.remove(filepath)
        return True

Common Deletion Vulnerabilities

  • File Fragments: Deleted files may leave fragments in slack space or temporary files
  • Backup Copies: Files may exist in backups, shadow copies, or cloud sync
  • Metadata Retention: Thumbnails, indexes, and caches may retain file information
  • Log Files: Application logs may contain file contents or paths
  • Swap/Page Files: Sensitive data may reside in virtual memory files
  • SSD Wear Leveling: Data may persist in unmapped blocks on SSDs
  • RAID Arrays: Data may exist on multiple drives in redundant arrays

import os
import glob
import subprocess

class ComprehensiveDeletion:
    def __init__(self, filepath):
        self.filepath = filepath
    
    def secure_remove_all(self):
        """Comprehensive deletion strategy"""

Best Practices for File Deletion

  • Understand the difference: Standard delete vs. secure delete for sensitive data
  • Use appropriate method: Recycle bin for accidental protection, secure delete for confidential data
  • Consider the storage medium: SSDs require TRIM support; HDDs can be overwritten
  • Check for copies: Ensure backups, shadows, and caches are also deleted
  • Verify deletion: Confirm file no longer appears in directory listings or recovery tools
  • For highly sensitive data: Use certified data destruction services or physical destruction
  • Implement retention policies: Automate deletion of old files based on business rules
  • Log deletions: Maintain audit trails for compliance and forensic purposes
  • Handle errors gracefully: Check permissions, locks, and dependencies before deletion
  • Consider alternatives: Encryption before deletion adds an extra layer of protection

Key Takeaways

  • Standard file deletion only removes directory entries; actual data remains on disk until overwritten
  • Secure deletion requires overwriting data before removing directory entries
  • SSDs complicate secure deletion due to wear-leveling; TRIM command helps but isn't foolproof
  • Modern NIST guidelines recommend single-pass overwrite for HDDs; multiple passes offer minimal additional security
  • Always consider backup copies, thumbnails, caches, and logs when deleting sensitive files
  • Different deletion methods suit different scenarios: soft delete for user data, secure delete for sensitive information
  • Recovery is often possible after standard deletion using forensic tools
  • For maximum security with sensitive data, combine secure deletion with encryption and physical destruction

   → If fast in Safe Mode, issue is software/driver related
   → If still slow, may be hardware or deep system issue

2. Check Task Manager for resource usage
   Ctrl + Shift + Esc → Performance tab
   → Identify if CPU, Memory, or Disk is bottleneck

3. Check Event Viewer for errors
   eventvwr.msc → Windows Logs → System
   → Look for errors occurring after update time

4. Uninstall recent updates
   Settings → Update & Security → View update history → Uninstall updates
   → Remove most recent update, restart

5. Update drivers (especially graphics, chipset)
   → Visit manufacturer website
   → Download and install latest drivers

6. Run System File Checker
   sfc /scannow
   → Repairs corrupted system files

7. If persists: System Restore to before update
   rstrui.exe → Choose restore point before update

Solution: Uninstalled problematic update KB5012345, updated graphics driver
Prevention: Pause updates during critical work periods, test updates on non-production system first

Scenario 2: Linux Won't Boot - Stuck at Black Screen

Problem: Ubuntu Linux shows black screen after login, no desktop appears

Troubleshooting Steps:

1. Access TTY terminal
   Press Ctrl + Alt + F3 (or F2-F6)
   → Login with username and password

2. Check disk space (common cause)
   df -h
   → If / (root) is at 100%, need to free space
   
3. Free up space if needed
   sudo apt clean
   sudo apt autoremove
   sudo journalctl --vacuum-time=3d

4. Check display manager status
   sudo systemctl status gdm3        # GNOME
   sudo systemctl status lightdm     # XFCE/Others
   
5. Restart display manager
   sudo systemctl restart gdm3

6. Check for graphics driver issues
   dmesg | grep -i error
   sudo ubuntu-drivers devices       # Check recommended drivers
   
7. Reinstall desktop environment (if corrupted)
   sudo apt install --reinstall ubuntu-desktop
   
8. Check .xsession-errors file
   cat ~/.xsession-errors
   → Look for error messages

9. Create new user account (test if user-specific)
   sudo adduser testuser
   → Login as testuser from TTY

Solution: Root partition full, cleared old logs and packages
Prevention: Set up log rotation, monitor disk space regularly

Preventive Troubleshooting

Preventing problems is easier than fixing them. Implement these best practices:

  • Regular Updates: Keep OS, drivers, and software updated with latest security patches
  • Backups: Maintain regular backups (3-2-1 rule: 3 copies, 2 different media, 1 offsite)
  • System Restore Points: Create restore points before major changes
  • Antivirus/Antimalware: Keep security software updated and run regular scans
  • Disk Maintenance: Regularly clean temporary files, defragment HDDs (not SSDs)
  • Monitor Health: Check disk health (S.M.A.R.T.), temperatures, and error logs
  • Documentation: Keep records of configurations, changes, and solutions
  • Testing: Test updates and changes in non-production environment first

Key Takeaways

  • Follow systematic troubleshooting methodology: identify, theorize, test, plan, implement, document
  • Use Safe Mode to isolate software and driver issues from hardware problems
  • System logs (Event Viewer, journalctl) are essential for diagnosing root causes of issues
  • Network troubleshooting follows OSI model: physical layer first, then logical layers
  • Boot issues often relate to corrupted boot files, failed drives, or BIOS/UEFI misconfiguration
  • Performance issues typically stem from resource exhaustion, malware, or failing hardware
  • Always create backups and restore points before making significant system changes
  • Documentation of problems and solutions builds knowledge base for future troubleshooting

  • macOS User Guide and Troubleshooting
  • How-To Geek - Troubleshooting Guides

Key Takeaways

  • PowerShell is the modern, preferred command-line interface for Windows with object-oriented capabilities
  • CMD remains useful for legacy scripts and simple tasks, but PowerShell offers far more power
  • Use Get-Help, Get-Command, and Get-Member to discover and learn PowerShell cmdlets

  • Process and service management cmdlets enable remote administration and automation
  • Piping and filtering in PowerShell work with objects, not just text like traditional shells
  • Many CMD commands have PowerShell equivalents with enhanced functionality
  • Understanding command redirection and piping enables complex automation and reporting

macOS is built on a Unix foundation (Darwin), combining BSD Unix with Apple's proprietary technologies. While sharing many commands with Linux, macOS includes unique commands and utilities for system management, security, and integration with Apple's ecosystem. For cybersecurity professionals, understanding macOS-specific commands is essential for securing Mac endpoints, conducting forensics, and managing Apple devices in enterprise environments.

Key Takeaways

  • macOS uses launchctl instead of systemctl for service management
  • Homebrew is essential for package management; install it first for security tools
  • diskutil is the primary disk management tool, more powerful than basic Unix commands
  • mdfind leverages Spotlight for faster file searches than traditional find
  • pbcopy and pbpaste provide clipboard access unavailable in standard Unix
  • networksetup offers comprehensive network configuration beyond ifconfig
  • Security features like FileVault, Gatekeeper, and SIP require specific macOS commands
  • defaults command allows system customization without GUI preferences
  • Many macOS commands require sudo and are located in /usr/libexec/
  • Understanding system_profiler and sysctl is crucial for system information gathering
